advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Compatible with you know who.<br> Equiped like nobody.<br> Priced like Amstrad".<br> <br> Single drive, monochrome monitor = 4997 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, monochrome monitor = 6290 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, colour monitor = 6890 FF + VAT<br> Double drive, colour monitor = 8190 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, monochrome monitor = 9990 FF + VAT<br> Single drive, 20 MB hard-disk, colour monitor = 11890 FF + VAT</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Pravetz Apple II compatible technology and price are compared with the IBM compatible Pravetz 8C.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b> for the English translation</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5500 ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a french advert for the ISTC 5500 published in january 1981. Its is exactly the same advert used for the model 5000, apart some modification in the description (disk drive capacity). Even the picture is still the same, with a "5" added with a pen, by hand !!!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As the first advert campaing was not a good idea, NEC of America replaced it with this one... which was not better</blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Motorola SC80801P + several other Motorola chips (RAM ?)
computer.description:
What a weird system we have here! This must be one of the rarest and most original consoles ever produced. It only plays one game: Star Chess, a version of chess which takes place in space, for two players.
The system itself looks like a box with a transparent plastic cover, revealing four silver controllers stored into the plastic case. Actually, only two of the silver oblongs are real controllers, attached by extendable wires to the console for 2 players. Another silver oblong opens out into the instruction manual, and the last one cannot be moved and contains sound on/off + power on/off switches and reset button.
Star Chess is based on the well known game of chess but your chessmen are space ships engaged in Galactic Warfare. The game board is laid out as a normal chessboard with space ships instead of chess pieces. Two players take turns moving their ships (no solo play). The rules and moves are based on chess but with some additions. You can fire missiles at your opponents, you have shields, you can get a damage report, you can return to base to stock up on missiles used up, and if you are in trouble you can warp into hyperspace. But beware, you can re-appear at anytime in a random position on the board and be in a worse situation! To win the game you have to destroy or capture your opponent's "commander" (king).
An interesting fact is that this game can also be found on Emerson Arcadia 2001 and compatible systems! So, some questions come to mind: is it the exact same game put in a standalone console (see the software page, we can see here that the two versions are not exactly the same)? Which version came first? What are the origins of this game? If you can answer these questions, please mail us!
At various stages the company was called Voltmace or Videomaster (owned by Waddingtons, a huge boardgame company). They released a console called Voltmace Database in 1978 (?) which was Interton VC-4000 "compatible", but never released an "Arcadia 2001 compatible system" able to play the famous Star Chess game. Maybe Videomaster did not want repeat the Voltmace Database experience, and decided, upon pressure from Waddingtons, to release only a standalone system playing a board game, Star Chess, using technology and software they had access to. Just a guess though...
Anyway, the system did not sell very well and is now an interesting collectors item.
Important, read the real story from the inventor himself, Peter Gebler, in the first comment below! _______________
Special thanks to Michael Davidson for his knowledge, which helped me write this.
computer.keyboard: Two detachable controllers (with direction buttons and different functions)
computer.name: Star Chess
